studies)..

made more strict, less strict, or remain as they are?" by Gallup, 40% are 
satisfied with current laws, 16% are dissatisfied and want less-strict 
laws, and 31% are dissatisfied and want stricter laws. That poll was 
conducted in January 2014.

comments.text:

comments.author: TheBaconWizard

comments.text:
+Miranox The proper definition is quite clear if you look at the history of 
the movement. It's anti-statist socialism that rejects the idea of 
vanguardism and generally advocates for the direct transition from state 
capitalism to direct democracy and workers self-management.
comments.author: LamentationsEnd

comments.text:
+LamentationsEnd
Everyone is making up their own definitions. This happens with a lot of 
these labels and it's why I consider them meaningless unless a clear and 
concise definition is given. That's why I use the dictionary definition.
comments.author: Miranox

comments.text:
+Miranox Only if your understanding of anarchism is based on a dictionary. 
It'd certainly be a controversial move for an anarchist to take, I'd 
certainly disagree with it, but it could potentially have anarchistic ends. 
For example, Eugene V Debs considered himself something of an anarchist and 
said that all socialists should be anarchists, but he ran for presidency.
comments.author: LamentationsEnd

comments.text: +Miranox Not quite a contradiction. It could be a means to an end.
comments.author: Mephistahpheles

comments.text:
+LamentationsEnd
The problem with an anarchist candidate for president should be obvious. 
It's a self-contradiction. It's like saying I want to be a married bachelor.
comments.author: Miranox

comments.text:
+LamentationsEnd Yup. I can easily pass for a radical conservative...or a 
radical liberal without *any* misinformation.

All I need to do is not mention stuff. I generally call myself liberal 
('cuz you'd have to be nuts to self-identify as conservative....at least, 
publicly.)

Fact is, some of the things I strongly believe are 'radically 
conservative'. (e.g. eliminate all business taxes except tariffs, smaller 
government, less regulation), and some are radically socialist 
(no-questions-asked 'welfare' for all), and some...err...I dunno what you'd 
call 'm.

So, what would a person call me? Mostly, depends on what they know about me.

Unusual? No, I think far more people are a mish-mash of left & right ideas 
than there are "puritans". Puritans are the scary ones...the sheeple.
comments.author: Mephistahpheles

comments.text:
+Mephistahpheles It's so insane. It's like, unless you believe in zero 
regulation, zero taxes and 100% imperialism, then you must be a hardcore 
rad Left Marxist-Leninist-Stalinist-Maoist-Trotskyist black panther 
communist just waiting to install a white genocide dictatorship. 

I'm glad the word anarchist hasn't been tainted as much, but lately it 
seems like whenever I call myself that, people assume I love Ron Paul. 
Which brings me to another thing; When the most anti-imperialist and 
anti-corporate candidate for president is Ron Paul, you know something is 
horribly wrong.
comments.author: LamentationsEnd

comments.text:
+Mephistahpheles

comments.author: christopher b

comments.text:
+Ayanle Mohamed exactly. What people like +Plato86  never seem to 
acknowledge is how interdependent we are in any civilized society. The 
right to live free does not come without a cost. We build roads and 
highways and have police and forest rangers etc. We educate our children 
and that is paid for,in some cases by people who will never have kids. I 
don't get to dictate where I want my money to go. I thought the Iraq war 
was incredibly stupid but I don't get to tell the government not to use my 
taxes for it. I am being forced to pay for many things I don't want or will 
never use,and in some cases disagree with,and I accept all of it as part of 
living in a thriving society. Somehow this one area of health insurance 
should be up to the individual? That's facism or socialism? Gimme a break.
comments.author: unkledave52

comments.text:

how healthcare insurance does affect other people like car insurance, it's 
time you realized that you are one of the dumb ones.
comments.author: James Lopez (Saikron)

comments.text:
+Plato86 That's the worst logic you have ever used. Healthcare effects us 
all because all tax payers pay for the uninsured. If you work for Walmart 
and you or your kid gets sick, you end up in the ER for basic treatment,and 
those services cost more at that point and all of us pay that bill. I had a 
friend who refused to pay for health insurance. When he had a motorcycle 
accident he received emergency treatment and surgery and rehab. Who do you 
think paid that bill. The cost of healthcare and making sure everyone is 
insured affects us all. It is disingenuous to claim otherwise.
comments.author: unkledave52

comments.text:
+שאול פגיס שרון Yes but that effect other people. Healthcare only effects
